title-group.article-title: Financing Policies and Practices in Large Corporations

abstract.p: This paper reports the results of a 1980 survey of 212 financial executives who work for large, industrial corporations. The study explores various aspects of financial structure management in these firms. Information is provided on the prevalence of using certain financial leverage metrics, on whether the executives subscribe to the traditional saucer-shaped average cost of capital curve, and on the methods in use for defining corporate debt capacity. Highly sophisticated notions of debt capacity were not evidenced in practice by the results of this survey.
